I loue another ⁊ ellis I were to blame .
Well bette than the bi Ihu Absolon .
Go forth thi weie or I will caste a ston .
And lete me slepe a twenti deuylwaie .
Allas ꝙquod Absolon ⁊ welaweie .
That trewe loue was euꝰer so euyll bi sette .
Than kisse me syn it may be no bette .
For ihus loue ⁊ for the loue of me .
Wilt thou than go thi way ther with ꝙquod sche .
Ye certis lēmman ꝙquod this Absolon .
Than make the redy ꝙquod sche I come a non .
And vn to Nicholas sche seide stille .
Now pees ⁊ thou shalt laugh all thi fille .
This Absolon doun sette hym on his knees .
And seide I am a lord at all degrees .
For after this I hope ther / cometh more .
Lemman thi grace ⁊ swete brid thyn ore .
The wyndow sche vndoth ⁊ that in hast .
Haue do ꝙquod sche come of ⁊ spede the fast .
Lest that our neighboris the espie .
This Absolon gan wipe his mouth full drie .
Derk was the nyght as picche or as the cole .
And at the wyndow out sche put here hole .
And Absolon hym fill no bet ne wers .
But with his mouthe he kist hir nakid ers .
Full sauourly or he was war of this .
A bak he sterte ⁊ thought it was a mys .
For well he wist a woman hath no berde .
He felt a thyng all rough ⁊ long herid .
And seide fy allas what haue I do .
Tehe ꝙquod sche ⁊ clapt the wyndow to .
And Absolon goth forth a sory paas .
A berde a berde seide hende Nicholas .
By goddis corpus this goth faire ⁊ well .
This sely Absolon herde it euꝰery dell .
And on his lippe he gan for angir bite .
And to hym self he seide I schall the quyte .
Who rubbith now who froteth now his lippes .
With dust wtith sonde with strawe wtith cloth wtith chippes .
¶ But Absolon that seieth full ofte allas .
Mi soule be take I to Satanas .
But me were leuyr than all this toun ꝙquod he .
Of this dispite a wroken for to be .
Allas ꝙquod he allas I ne had bleynt .
His hoot loue is colde ⁊ all queynt .
For fro that tyme that he had kist hir ers .
Of ꝑperamorurs he sette not a kers .
For he was helid of his maladie .
Full ofte ꝑperamorurs he gan defie .
A wepe as doth a childe that is bete .
A softe paas he wente ouer the strete .
Vn till a smyth men clepen daun Geruais .
That in his forge smythieth plough harnais .
He scharpeth scharre ⁊ Culter bisily .
This Absolon knokketh all esely .
And seide vn to Gerueis ⁊ that a non .
¶ What who artow . yt am I Absolon .
What Absolon what ciristis swete tre .
Whi rise ye so rathe ey benedicite .
What eileth you som gay gerle god it woot /
Hath brought you thus on the viritot /
By seynt note ye woot weell what I mene .
This Absolon ne rought not a bene .
Of all his pleie no word a geyn he gaf .
He had more tow on his distaf .
Than Geruays knewe . ⁊ seide frend so dere .
The hote Culter in the chemenye here .
As lene it me I haue ther with to done .
I woll bryng it a geyn full sone .
Geruais answerde certis were it golde .
Or in a poke noblis all vn tolde .
Thou schuldist haue it as I am trew smyth .
Ey ciristes foo what will ye don ther with .
¶ Ther of ꝙquod Absolon be as be may .
I schall well tellen it the to morow day .
And caught the Culter bi the colde stele .
Full softe oute atte dore he gan stele .
And wente vn to the Carpenters wall .
He coughede first ⁊ knokked ther with all .
Vp on the wyndow right as he did ere .
This Alison answerde who is there .
That knokketh so I warante it a thef .
Whi nay ꝙquod he god woot my swete lef .
I am thyn Absolon thyn derelyng .
Of golde ꝙquod he I haue the brought a ryng .
My modir yaf it me so god me saue .
Full fyn it is ⁊ ther to well graue .
This woll I yeuyn the if thou me kisse .
This Nicholas was risen for to pisse .
And thought he wolde amenden all the iape .
He schulde kisse his ers or that he schape .
And vp the wyndow did he hastily .
And out his ers he put pryuely .
Ouer the buttok to the haunche bon .
And therwith spak this clerke this Absolon .
Speke swete bridde I not where thou art .
This Nicholas a noon leet flee a fart .
As gret as it hadde ben a thondir dent .
That with the stroke he was almost blent .
And he was redy with his yren hoot .
And Nicholas in the ers he smoot .
Of goth the skyn an hondebrode a boute .
The hote Culter brenned so his toute .
And for the smerte he wende for to dye .
As he were wood for wo he gan to crye .
Helpe water water helpe for goddis herte .
This Carpenter out of his slomber sterte .
And herd oon crien water as he were wood .
And thought allas now cometh Noes flood .
And sette hym vp with oute wordis mo .
And with an axe he smot the corde a two .
And doun goth all he fonde neither to selle .
No bred nor ale till he come to the selle .
Vp on the floor ⁊ there a swoune he lay .
Vp sterte hir Alison ⁊ Nicholay .
And cried out ⁊ harrow in the strete .
The neighboris bothe smale ⁊ grete .
In ronnen for to gauren on this man .
That a swoune lay bothe pale ⁊ wan .
For with that fall he brosten hath his arm .
But stonden he moste vn to his owne harm .
For whan he spak he was a noon bore doun .
With hende Nicholas ⁊ Alison .
Thei tolde euꝰery man that he was wood .
He was a gaste so of the Noes flood .
Thorugh fantasie that of his vanyte .
He had bought hym knedyng tubbis thre .
And had hem hanged in the roof a boue .
And that he praied hym for goddis loue .
To sitten in the roof ꝑper companye .
The folk gan laughen at his fantasie .
And to the roof thei kiken ⁊ thei gape .
And turned all his harm vn to a iape .
For what so this Carpenter / answerde .
It was for nought no man his reson herde .
With othes grete he was so sworn a doun .
That he was holden wood in all the toun .
For euery clerke a noon right helde with other .
Thei seide the man is wood my leue brother
And euꝰery wight gan laughwen at his strif .
Thus swyued was the Carpenters wif .
For all his kepyng ⁊ his ielousie .
And Absolon hath kist hir nethir ye .
And Nicholas is scaldid in his toute .
This tale is don ⁊ god saue all the route .
Here endeth the Millers tale

div.l: (base) ¶ The Prologe / of the Reues tale
(base) Whan folk hadde laughen / at this nyce cas
(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
(base) Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
(base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
(base) Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
(base) We olde men / I drede so fare we
(base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
(base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
(base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
(base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
(base) And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
(base) Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
(base) The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
(base) The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
(base) Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
(base) With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
(base) He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
(base) He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
(base) The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
(base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
(base) Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
(base) Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
(base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
(base) I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
(base) Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
(base) For leueful is / with force / force of showue
(base) This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
(base) How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
(base) And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
(base) Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
(base) I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
(base) He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
(base) But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke
(base) ¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
(base) And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
(base) And by his belt he baar a long panade
(base) And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade
(base) A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
(base) Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
(base) A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
(base) Round was his face and camuse was his nose
(base) As piled as an Ape was his skulle
(base) He was a Market beter at the fulle
(base) Ther dorste no wight hand vp on hym legge
(base) That he ne swoor he sholde anon abegge
(base) A theef he was for sothe of corn and mele
(base) And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
(base) His name was hoten deynous Symkyn
(base) A wif he hadde comen of noble kyn
(base) The person of the toun hir fader was
(base) With hir he yaf ful many a panne a bras
(base) For that Symkyn sholde in his blood allye
(base) She was yfostred in a Nonnerye
(base) For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he sayde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But she were wel ynorissed and a mayde
(base) To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
(base) And she was proud and peert as is a pye
(base) A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
(base) On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
(base) With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
(base) And she cam after in a gyte of reed
(base) And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
(base) Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
(base) Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
(base) That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
(base) But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
(base) With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
(base) For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
(base) Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
(base) And eek for she was som del smoterlich
(base) She was as digne as water in a dich
(base) And ful of hoker and of bismare
(base) Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
(base) What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
(base) That she hadde lerned in the Nonnerye
(base) A doghter hadde they bitwix hem two
(base) Of twenty yeer with outen any mo
(base) Sauyng a child that was of hal yeer age
(base) In Cradel it lay and was a propre page
(base) This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was
(base) With camuse nose and eyen greye as glas
(base) With buttokes brode and brestes rounde and hye
(base) But right fair was hir heer I wol nat lye
(base) The person of the toun for she was so feir
(base) In purpos was to maken hir his heir
(base) Bothe of his catel and his Mesuage
(base) And straunge he made it of hir mariage
(base) His purpos was to makyn hir his eire
(base) His purpos was for to bistowe hir hye
(base) In to som worthy blood of Auncetrye
(base) For holicherches good moot been despended
(base) On holicherches blood that is descended
(base) Ther fore he wolde his holy blood honoure
(base) Thogh that he holy chirche sholde deuoure
(base) Greet sokne hath this Miller out of doute
(base) With whete and malt of al the land aboute
(base) And nameliche ther was a greet Collegge
(base) Men clepeth the soler halle at Cantebregge
(base) Ther was hir whete and eek hir malt ygrounde
(base) And on a day it happed in a stounde
(base) Syk was this maunciple on a maladie

div.l: (base) Men wenden wisly that he sholde dye
(base) For which this Millere stal bothe mele and corn
(base) An hondred tyme moore than biforn
(base) For ther biforn he stal but curteisly
(base) But now he was a theef outrageously
(base) For which the wardeyn chidde and made fare
(base) But ther of sette the Millere noght a tare
(base) He craked boost and swoor it was noght so
(base) Thanne were ther yonge poure scolers two
(base) That dwelten in the halle of which I seye
(base) Testyf they were and lusty for to pleye
(base) And oonly for hir myrthe and reuerye
(base) Vp on the wardeyn bisily they crye
(base) To yeue hem leue but a litel stounde
(base) To go to Mille and seen hir corn ygrounde
(base) And hardily they dorste leye hir nekke
(base) The Millere sholde noght stelen hem half a pekke
(base) Of corn by sleighte ne by force hem reue
(base) And at the laste the wardeyn yaf hem leue
(base) Iohn highte that oon and Aleyn highte that oother
(base) Of oon town were they born that highte Strother
(base) Fer in the North I kan noght telle where
(base) This Aleyn maketh redy al his gere
(base) They makyn redy al hir owen gere
(base) And on an hors the sak he caste anon
(base) Forth gooth Aleyn the clerk. and also Iohn
(base) With good swerd and with bokeler by his syde
(base) Iohn knew the wey hym neded no gyde
(base) And at the Mille the sak adoun he layth
(base) Aleyn spak first alhayl Symkyn in fayth
(base) How fares thy faire doghter and thy wyf
(base) Aleyn wel come quod Symkyn by my lyf
(base) And Iohn also how now what do ye here
(base) By god quod Iohn . Symond nede has na peere
(base) Hym bihoues serue hym self that has na swayn
(base) Or ellis he is a fool as clerkes sayn
(base) Oure maunciple I hope he wol be deed
(base) Swa werkes ay the wanges in his heed
(base) And ther fore is I come and eek Alayn
(base) To grynde oure corn and carie it heem agayn
(base) I pray yow speed vs heythen what ye may
(base) It shal be doon quod Symkyn by my fay
(base) What wol ye doon whil that it is in hande
(base) By god right by the hoper wol I stande
(base) Quod Iohn and se how the corn gas In
(base) Yet saw I neuere by my fader kyn
(base) How that the hoper wagges til and fra
(base) Aleyn answerde Iohn wiltow swa
(base) Thanne wol I be byneth by my crown

div.l: (base) And se how that the mele falles down
(base) In to the trogh that sal be my desport
(base) For Iohn in faith I may been of youre sort
(base) I is as ille a Millere as ar ye
(base) This Millere smyled of hir nycetee
(base) And thoghte al this nys doon but for a wyle
(base) They wene that no man may hem bigile
(base) But by my thrift yet shal I blere hir Iye
(base) For al the sleighte in hir phislophye
(base) The moore queynte crekys that they make
(base) The moore wol I stele whan I take
(base) In stede of flour yet wol I yeue hem bren
(base) The grettest clerkes been noght the wisest men
(base) As whilom to the wolf thus spak the mare
(base) Of al hir art counte I noght a tare
(base) Out of the dore he gooth ful pryuely
(base) Whan that he saugh his tyme softely
(base) He looketh vp and doun til he hath founde
(base) The clerkes hors ther as it stood ybounde
(base) Bihynde the Mille vnder a leefsel
(base) And to the hors he gooth hym faire and wel
(base) He strepeth of the bridel right anon
(base) And whan the hors was laus he gynneth gon
(base) Toward the fen ther wilde mares renne
(base) And forth with wehe thurgh thikke and thenne
(base) This Millere gooth ayein no word he seyde
(base) But dooth his note and with the clerkes pleyde
(base) Til that hir corn was faire and wel ygrounde
(base) And whan the mele was sakked and ybounde
(base) This Iohn gooth out and fynt his hors away
(base) And gan to crye harrow and weilaway
(base) Oure hors is lost. Alayn for goddes banes
(base) Step on thy feet com of man al atanes
(base) Allas oure wardeyn has his palfrey lorn
(base) This Alayn al forgat bothe mele and corn
(base) Al was out of his mynde his housbondrye
(base) What whilk wey is he gane he gan to crye
(base) The wyf cam lepyng Inward with a ren
(base) She seyde allas youre hors gooth to the fen
(base) With wilde mares as faste as he may go
(base) Vnthank come on his hand that boond hym so
(base) And he that bettre sholde haue knyt the reyne
(base) Allas quod Iohn Aleyn for Cristes peyne
(base) Lay doun thy swerd and I wol myn alswa
(base) I is ful wight god waat as is a ra
(base) By god hert he sal nat scape vs bathe
(base) Be cockis herte he shal not a scape vs bathe
(base) Why ne had thow pit the capil in the lathe

div.l: (base) Ilhail by god Alayn thow is a fonne
(base) This sely clerkes haan ful faste yronne
(base) Toward the fen bothe Alayn and eek Iohn
(base) And whan the Millere seigh that they were gon
(base) He half a busshel of hir flour hath take
(base) And bad his wyf go knede it in a cake
(base) He seyde I trowe the clerkes were aferd
(base) Yet kan a Millere maken a clerkes berd
(base) For al his art ye lat hem goon hir weye
(base) Lo wher he gooth ye lat the children pleye
(base) They gete hym noght so lightly by my croun
(base) Thise sely clerkes rennen vp and doun
(base) With keep keep stand stand Iossa warderere
(base) Ga whistle thow and I sal kepe hym heere
(base) But shortly til that it was verray nyght
(base) They koude noght thogh they dide al hir myght
(base) Hir capyl cacche he ran alwey so faste
(base) Til in a dych they caughte hym at the laste
(base) Wery and weet as beest is in the reyn
(base) Comth sely Iohn and with hym comth Aleyn
(base) Allas quod Iohn the day that I was born
(base) Now ar we dryuen til hethyng and til scorn
(base) Oure corn is stole men wil vs foolis calle
(base) Bothe the wardeyn and oure felawes alle
(base) And namely the Millere weilawey
(base) Thus pleyneth Iohn as he gooth by the wey
(base) Toward the Mille and Bayard in his hond
(base) The Millere sittyng by the fyr he fond
(base) For it was nyght and ferther myghte they noght
(base) But for the loue of god they hym bisoght
(base) Of herberwe and of ese as for hir peny
(base) The Millere seide agayn if ther be eny
(base) Swich as it is yet shal ye haue youre part
(base) Myn hous is streyt but ye han lerned art
(base) Ye kan by argumentz make a place
(base) A myle brood of twenty foot of space
(base) Lat se now if this place may suffise
(base) Or make it rowm with speche as is your gyse
(base) Now Symond seyde this Iohn by Seint Cutberd
(base) Ay is thou myrie and that is faire answerd
(base) I haue herd seye men sal tak of twa thynges
(base) Swilk as he fyndes or tak swilk as he brynges
(base) But specialy I pray thee hoost deere
(base) Get vs som mete and drynke and make vs cheere
(base) And we wol payen trewely at the fulle
(base) With empty hand men may none haukes tulle
(base) Lo heere oure siluer redy for to spende

div.l: (base) This Millere in to town his doghter sende
(base) For ale and breed and rosted hem a goos
(base) And boond hir hors it sholde namoore go loos
(base) And in his owene chambre hem made a bed
(base) With shetes and with chalons faire yspred
(base) Noght from his owene bed but ten foot or twelue
(base) His doghter hadde a bed al by hir selue
(base) Right in the same chambre by and by
(base) It myghte be no bet and cause why
(base) Ther was no rowmer herberwe in the place
(base) They soupen and they speken hem to solace
(base) And drynken euere stroong ale at the beste
(base) Aboute mydnyght wente they to reste
(base) Wel hath this Millere vernysshed his heed
(base) Ful pale he was for dronke and noght reed
(base) He yexeth and he speketh thurgh the nose
(base) As he were on the quakke or on the pose
(base) To bedde he goth and with hym goth his wyf
(base) As any Iay she light was and iolyf
(base) So was hir ioly whistle wel ywet
(base) The Cradel at hir beddes feet is set
(base) To rokken and to yeue the child to sowke
(base) And whan that dronken al was in the Crowke
(base) To bedde wente the doghter right anon
(base) To bedde gooth Aleyn and also Iohn
(base) Ther nas namoore hem neded no dwale
(base) This Millere hath so wisly bibbed ale
(base) That as an hors he fnorteth in his sleep
(base) Ne of his tayl bihynde he took no keep
(base) His wyf bar hym a burdon a ful strong
(base) Men myghten hir routyng heren a furlong
(base) The wenche routeth eek per compaignye
(base) Aleyn the clerc that herde this melodye

And loke that thou reporte his name welle .
Sir ꝙquod this knaue it nedeth neuyr a delle .
Hit was me tolde er ye come here two houres .
He was ꝑperde an olde felawe of youres .
All sodenly was he slayn to nyght .
For dronken as he satte vp on his benche a vp right .
Ther come a pryue theef men clepen deeth .
That in his contrarie all the peple sleeth .
And with his spere he smote his hert a two .
And went his weie with oute wordis mo .
He hath a thousand slayn this pestilence .
And maister er ye come in his presence .
Me thynketh that it were necessarie .
For to be waar of suche an aduersarie .
Beth redy for to mete hym euꝰermore .
Thus taught me my dame I say no more .
Bi seynt Marie seide this tauernere .
The childe saith soth for he hath slayn to yere .
Hennes ouyr a myle with yn a gret vilage .
Both man ⁊ woman childe ⁊ page .
I trowe his habitacion be there .
To ben a vised gret wisdom it were .
Or that he did a man dishonour .
Ye goddis armes ꝙquod this riotour .
Is it suche ꝑperill with hym for to mete .
I schall hym sechyn be stye ⁊ be strete .
I make a vow bi goddis digne bones .
Herkeneth felawes we thre ben alle ones .
Lete vche of vs holde vp his honde to other .
And eche of vs bicome other brother .
And we will sle this fals traitour deth .
He schall be slayn he that so many sleth .
Bi goddis dignyte er it be nyght .
To gider han these thre her hertis plight .
To lyue ⁊ to dye ilke of hem with other .
As thogh he were his owne borne brother .
And vp thei stertyn ⁊ dronken in this rage .
And forth thei gon toward that vilage .
Of whiche the tauerner hath spoken bi forne .
And mony a grisly othe then han thei sworne .
And cristes blessid body thei to rent .
That deth schall be deed if that we may hym hent .
When thei han goon not fully a myle .
Right as thei wolde haue troden ouꝰer a stile .
An olde pore man with hem mette .
This olde man full mekely hem grette .
And seide thus now lordis god you se .
The proudest of these riotours thre .
Answerid a yen what cherle with hard grace .
Whi art thou all for wrappid saue thi face .
Whi lyuest thou so long in so gret age .
This olde man gan loke in his visage .
And seide thus for I can not fynde .
A man though I walked in to ynde .
Neither in Cite ne in non vilage .
That will changen his yougthe for myn age .
And therfore mote I haue myn age stille .
As long tyme as it is goddis wille .
Ne deth alas will not haue my lif .
Thus walke I like a resteles caitif .
And on the grounde whiche is my moder gate .
I knok with my staf erly ⁊ late .
¶ And say leue moder late me ynne .
Low how I wansche flesche blood ⁊ skynne .
Alas whan schull my bones ben at reste .
Moder with you wolde I change my cheste .
That in my chambre long tyme hath be .
Ye for an hier cloute to wrappe me .
But yet to me sche will not do that grace .
For whiche full welked is my face .
But sirs to you it is no curtesie .
To speken vn till an olde man vilanye .
But he trespace in word or ellis in dede .
In holy writte ye may your self well rede .
¶ A yenst an olde man hoor vp on his heed .
Ye schulde a rise you therfore I yeue you reed .
Ne doth vn to an olde man harme as now .
No more than ye wolde a man dide yow .
In age if that ye so long a bide .
And god be with you whether ye go or ride .
I mote go thedir as I haue to go .
Nay olde chirle bi god thou schalt not so .
Seide thes other hasardours a non .
Thou partist not so lightly be seynt Iohn .
Thou spake right now of thilke traitour deeth .
That in this contray alle our frendis sleeth .
Haue here my trouthe as thou art his a spie .
Tell where he is or ellis thou schalt die .
Bi god ⁊ bi the holy sacrament .
For sothely thou art of his assent .
To sleen vs yong folk thou fals theef .
Now sirs if it be to you so leef .
To fynde deth turne vp this croked weie .
For in that groue I lefte hym be my feie .
Vndir a tre ⁊ ther he woll a bide .
Ne for your bost he will hym no thyng hide .
Se ye that Oke right ther ye schull hym fynde .
God saue you that bought a yen man kynde .
¶ And you amende thus seide this olde man .
And euery of thes riatours ran .
Till thei come to the tre ⁊ ther thei founde .
Floreyns of golde fyne y coyned rounde .
Well nygh a seuyn buschels as hem thought .
No lenger than after deth thei sought .
But eche of hem so glad was of that sight .
For that the floreyns so faire be ⁊ bright .
That doun thei sette hem bi the precious horde .
The wurst of hem he spake the first worde .
Bretheren ꝙquod he take hede what I saye .
Mi witte is greet though I bourde ⁊ playe .
This tresour hath fortune to vs yeuyn .
In myrthe ⁊ iolite our lif to lyuen .
And lightly so as it cometh so will we spende .
Eye precious goddis hert who wende .
To day that we schulde haue so faire a grace .
But myght this golde be caried fro this place .
Home vn to my hous or ellis to yours .
For well I woot that all this golde is ours .
Then were we in high felicite .
But truly be daye it may not be .
Men wolde sayn that we weren theefis strong .
And for our owne tresour done vs hong .
As wisely ⁊ as sleighly as it myght .
This tresour most caried be bi nyght .
Wherfore I rede lete loke among vs alle .
So drawe ⁊ lete se wher the cut will falle .
He that hath the curt with hert blithe .
Schall renne to towne ⁊ that full swithe .
To bryng vs breed ⁊ drynk full pryuely .
And two of vs schull kepen full subtilly .
This tresour well ⁊ if he will not tarye .
When it is nyght we will this tresour carie .
Bi oon assent wher as vs liketh beste .
That oon of hem brought gras in his feste .
And bad hem drawe ⁊ loke on whom it woll falle .
And it fell on the yongest of hem alle .
And forth towarde the towne he wente a noon .
And also sone as he was goon .
That oon of hem spake vn to that other .
Thou wost well thou art myn owne sworn brothe .
Thyn profite woll I telle the a noon .
Thou wost well that our felawe is goon .
And here is golde ⁊ that right gret plente .
That it schall deꝑpertid be among vs thre .
But natheles if I can schape it so .
That it deꝑpertid were among vs two .
Had I not doon a frendis turne to the .
That other answerde I not how that myght be .
I wolde well that the gold were ours two .
What schulde we do that it myght be so .
Schall it be counseile seide the first schrewe .
And I schall tellen the in wordis fewe .
What we schull don ⁊ bryng it a boute .
I graunt ꝙquod that other out of doute .
That bi trouthe I will the not be wreien .
Now ꝙquod the first thou wost well we ben tweien .
And two of vs schull strenger be than oon .
Loke when he is sette ⁊ that a non .
A rise as though thou woldist with hym pleie .
And I schall ryuen hym thorogh the sides tweie .
Whiles that thou strogelist with hym as in game .
And with thi dagger loke thou do the same .
And then schall all this golde deꝑpertid be .
Mi dere frende bitwixe the ⁊ me .
Then may we bothe our lustis fulfille
And pleie at the dyce right at our owne wille .
And thus a corded ben these schrewes tweie .
To sle the thrid as ye herd me seie .
¶ This yongest whiche that went to the toun .
Full ofte in his hert it rollid vp ⁊ doun .
The beaute of thes floreyns faire ⁊ bright .
O lord ꝙquod he if it so were I myght .
Haue all this tresour to my self allone .
Ther is no man that lyueth vnder trone .
Of golde that schulde lyue as mery as I .
And at the last the fende our enemy .
Put in his thought that he schulde poyson bey .
With whiche he myght sleen his felawes twey .
For whi the fende fonde hym in suche lyuyng .
That he had leue hym to sorow bryng .
For this was outerly his entent .
To sleen hem bothe ⁊ neuyr to repent .
And forth he goth no lenger wolde he tarie .
In to the towne vn to apoticarie .
And preide hym that he hym wolde selle .
Some poisen that he myght his rattes quelle .
And eke ther was a pulkat in his hawe .
That as he seide his Capons had y slawe .
And seide he wolde wreke hym if he myght .
Of vermyn that distroied hym be nyght .
The Poticarie answerde thou schalt haue .
A thyng that als god my soule saue .
In all this worlde ther is no creature .
That ete or drynke of this confecture .
Noght but the moūntaunce of a corne of whete .
That he ne schall his lif a non for lete .
Ye sterue he schall ⁊ that in lasse while .
Than thou wolt goon a pace not but a myle .
This poyson that is so hard ⁊ violent .
This cursid man hath in his honde hit hent
This poison in a box he put ⁊ sithens he ran .
In to the next strete vn to a man .
And borwid hym large botellis thre .
To his felawes a yen repaireth he .
The thrid he kept clene for his drynke .
For all the nyght he schope hym to swynke .
In cariyng of that golde out of that place .
And when this riatour with sory grace .
Had filled with hym his grete botellis thre .
To his felawis a yen repeireth he .
What nedeth it to sermon ther of more .
For right as thei had cast his deth bi fore .
Right so thei han hym slayn ⁊ that a non .
And when that this was don than spak that on .
Now lete vs sitte ⁊ drynk ⁊ make vs mery .
And afterward we woleth his body bury .
And after that it happed hem ꝑper cas .
To taken þe botell wher yn the poison was .
And dranke ⁊ yaf his felawe drynk also .
Thorogh whiche a non thei steruyn bothe two .
¶ But certis I suppose that a phisicien .
Wrote neuyr in non canoūn ne in no fen .
Mo wondir sorowes of enpoisenyng .
Thus had thes wrecches two her endyng
Thus endid ben thes homycides two .
And eke this fals enpoisoner also .
O cursid synne full of all cursidnes .
O traitours homycides o wickednes .
O glotonye luxurie ⁊ hasardye .
Thou blasphemour of crist with vilanye .
And othes grete of vsage ⁊ of pride .
Alas mankynde how may it be tide .
That to thi creatour whiche that the wrought .
And with his precious blood the bought .
Thou art so fals ⁊ so vnkynde alas .
Now good men god for yue you your trespas .
And kepe you fro the synne of Auarice .
Myn holy ꝑperdon maye you alle warische .
So that ye offre noblis or starlyngis .
Or ellis siluer spones broches or rynges .
Bowith your heed vndir this bulle .
Cometh vp ye wifes offreth your wulle .
Your name I entre here in my rolle a non .
In to the blis of heuyn schull ye alle gon .
I you assoile be myn hye power .
Ye that wolen offre as clene ⁊ eke as cleer .
As ye were born ⁊ lo sirs thus I preche .
And ihūn crist that is our soules leche .
So graunt you this ꝑperdon to receyue .
For that is best I woll you not deceyue .
But sirs oo word for gate I in my tale .
I haue relikes ⁊ ꝑperdon in my male .
As faire as eny man in Engelonde .
Whiche were yeue me bi the popes honde .
Yef any of you will of deuocion .
Offren ⁊ han myn absolucion .
Cometh forth a non ⁊ kneleth here a doun .
That ye may haue part of my ꝑperdoun .
Or ellis taketh ꝑperdoūn as ye wende .
All newe ⁊ fresche at euery townes ende .
So that ye offren alweie newe ⁊ newe .
Nobles ⁊ pans whiche that ben good ⁊ trewe .
Hit is an honour to euꝰery that ben here .
That ye may haue a sufficiant ꝑperdonere .
To assoile you in contre as ye ride .
For auentures whiche that may be tide .
For ꝑperauenture ther may fall oon or two .
Downe of his hors ⁊ breke his necke a two .
Loke whiche assuerte it is to you alle .
That I am in your felaschip falle .
That may assoile you bothe more ⁊ lasse .
When that the soule schall fro the body passe .
I rede that our oost schall be gynne .
For he is most enuolupte of synne .
Come forth sir oost ⁊ offre first a non .
And thou schalt kisse the relikes euerichon .
Ye for a grote vn bokell a non thy purs .
Nay nay ꝙquod he than haue I cristes curs .
Lete be ꝙquod he it schall not be so theche .
Thou woldist maken me kisse thyn olde breche .
And swere it were the relike of a seynt .
Thogh it were with thi foūndement depeynt .
But bi the crois whiche seynt Elyne fonde .
I wolde I had thi coiliones in my honde .
In stede of relikes or of seynt wary .
Let cut hem of ⁊ I will helpe hem cary .
Thei schulde be schryned in a hogges torde .
¶ This ꝐPerdoner answerde not a worde .
So wroth he was he wolde no word saye .
Now ꝙquod our oost I will no lenger playe .
With the ne with non other angry man .
But right a non the worthi knyght bi gan .
When that he sawe that all the peple lough .
No more of this for it is right y nough .
Sir ꝐPerdoner be mery ⁊ glad of chere .
And ye sir oost that ben to me so dere .
I praye you that ye kisse the ꝑperdoner .
And ꝑperdoner I praye you drawe you ner .
And as we dide lete vs laugh ⁊ pleie .
And a non thei kissed ⁊ riden forth her weie .
Here endith the tale of the Pardoner .

A Marchaunt whilom dwellid at seynt Denys
That riche was for whiche men held hym wys
A wif he had of excellent beaute
And companable ⁊ reuꝰerent was sche
Whiche is a thyng that causeth more dispence
Then worth is all the chier ⁊ reuerence
That men hem done at festis ⁊ at daunces
Suche salutacions ⁊ contynaunces
Passeth as doth the schadow vpon a wall
But wo is hym that paien mote for all
The sely husbonde algate he mote paie
He mote vs clothe ⁊ vs araye
All for his owne worschip richely
In whiche araye we dauncen iolily
And if that he may not ꝑperauenture
Or ellis lust noon suche dispence endure
But thynketh that it is wast ⁊ lost
Then mote another paien for our cost
Or lene vs golde ⁊ that is ꝑperilous
This noble Marchaunt helde a noble hous
For whiche he had all daye gret repaire
For his largesse ⁊ for his wif was faire
That wondir is but herkeneth to my tale
Amongis alle his gestis grete ⁊ smale
Ther was a monke a faiore man ⁊ a bolde
I trowe thritti wynter he was olde
That euyr in oon was drawying to that place
This yong Monk that was so faire of face
Aqueyntid was so with th that good man
And eke this Monke of whiche I began
Were bothe two borne in oo vilage
The Monk hym claymed as for cosynage
And he ayen saith not ones nay
But was as glad ther of as foule of day
For to his herte it was agret plesaunce
Thus ben thei knyt with eterne aliaunce
And ilke of hem gan other assure
Of bretherhede whiles that her lif may dure
Fre was dan Iohn ⁊ namely of dispence
As in that hous ⁊ full of diligence
To do plesaunce ⁊ also gret costage
He noght for yate to yeue the lest page
In all that hous but after her degre
He yaf the lord ⁊ sithens his meyne
When that he cam some maner honest thyng
For whiche thei were as glad of his comyng
As foule is fayn when the sonne vp riseth
No more her of as now for this suffiseth
But so bifell this Marchaunt on a daye
Schope hym to make redy his araye
Towarde the toun of Bruggis for to fare
To byen ther a porcioun of ware
For whiche he hath to Parys sent anon
A messanger ⁊ praied hath dan Iohn
That he schulde come to seynt Denys to pleie
With hym ⁊ with his wif a daye or tweie
Or he to brugges went in all wise
This noble monk of whiche I you deuyse
Hath of his Abbot as hym list licence
Bicause he was a man of hye prudence
And eke an officere out for to ride
To seen her granges ⁊ her bernes wide
And vnto seynt Denys he cometh anon
Who was so well come as my lord dan Iohn
Our dere cosyn full of curtesie
With hym broght he a Iubbe of maluesie
And eke another full of fyn vernage
As volatile as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem ete ⁊ drynke ⁊ pleie
This marchaunt ⁊ this Monk a daye or tweie
The thrid daye this Marchaunt vp ariseth
And on his nede sadly hym a viseth
And vp in to his countarare hous goth he
To rekene with hym self as well may be
Of thilke yere how that it with hym stood
And how he dispendid had his good
And if that he encresid were or non
His bokes ⁊ his bagges many oon
He leieth to fore hym on his coūntyng bord
Full riche was his tresour ⁊ his hord
For whiche full fast his counter dore he schette
And eke he nolde that no man schulde hym lette
Of his acomptes for the mene tyme
And thus he sitte till it was passed pryme
Dan Iohn was risen in the morne also
And in the gardyn walked to ⁊ fro
And hath his thyngis seide full curteisly
This good wif came walkyng pryuely
In to the gardyn ther he walked softe
And hym salueth as sche hath done ofte
A maiden childe cam in hir companye
Which as hir lust sche may gouerne ⁊ gye
For yet vndir the yerd was the maide
O dere Cosyn myn dan Iohn sche saide
What eileth you so rathe for to arise
Nece ꝙquod he it aught ynough suffise
Fyue hours for to slepe vp on a nyght
But it were for an olde palled wight
As ben these weddid men that lye ⁊ dare
As in a forme sitte a wery hare
Were all for straught with houndis grete ⁊ smale
But dere Nece whi ben ye so pale
I trowe certis that our good man
Hath you labored sith the nyght began
That you were nede to resten hastely
And with that word he lough full merily
And of his owne thought he waxe all reed
This faire wif gan to schake hir heed
And seide thus ye god woot all ꝙquod sche
Nay Cosyn myn it stant not so with me
For bi that god that yaf me soule ⁊ lif
In all the reamme of Fraunce is ther no wif
That lasse lust hath to that sory playe
For I may syngen allas ⁊ welawaye
That I was born but to no wight ꝙquod sche
I dar not tellen how it stant with me
Wherfore I thenke out of this londe to wende
Or ellis of my self to make an ende
So full I am of drede ⁊ eke of care
This Monk bigan vpon this wif to stare
And seide allas my Nece god for bede
That ye for any sorow or any drede
For do your self but telleth me your gref
ꝐPerauenture I may in your myschef
Counseile or helpe ⁊ therfore telleth it me
All your a vys for it schall be secre
For on my portos I make an othe
That neuyr in my lif for lef ne lothe
Ne schall I of no counseile you be wreie
The same a yen to you ꝙquod sche I seie
Bi god ⁊ bi this portous I swere
Theigh men me wolde all in to pecis tere
Ne schall I neuyr for to go to helle
Be wreie a word of thyng that yi me telle
Noght for no cosynage ne alliaunce
But verraily for loue ⁊ affiaunce
Thus ben thei sworne ⁊ here vp on kiste
And ilke of hem tolde other what hem liste
Cosyn ꝙquod sche if I had a space
As I haue non namely in this place
Thēm wolde I tellen a legende of my lif
What I suffred haue sethyn I was a wif
Wtith my husbonde all theigh he be your cosyn
Nay ꝙquod this Monk bi god ⁊ be seynt Martyn
He is no more cosyn vn to me
Than is this leef that hangeth on the tre
I clepe hym so be seynt Denys in Fraunce
To haue the more cause of a queyntaunce
Of you whiche I haue louyd specially
Abouen alle women sikerly
This swere I you on my ꝓprofessioun
Telleth your greef lest he come a doun
And hasteth you ⁊ goth your waye anon
Mi dere loue ꝙquod sche o dan Iohn
Full lef me were this counseile to hide
But out it mote it may no more a bide
Myn husbonde is to me the worste man
That euyr was sith the worlde bigan
But sithen I am a wif it sitte not to me
To telle no wight of our pryuete
Neither in bedde ne in non other place
God schilde I schulde telle it for his grace
A wif ne schall not saye of hir husbonde
But all honour as I con vndirstonde
Saue vnto you thus moche telle I schall
As helpe me god he is not worth at all
In no degre the value of a flie
But yet me greueth moste his nygardye
And well ye woot that women naturelly
Desireth thynges six as well as I
Thei wolden that her husbonde schulde be
Hardy ⁊ wis riche ⁊ ther to fre
And buxom to his wif ⁊ fresche a bedde
But bi that ilke lord that for vs bledde
For his honour my self to araye
On sondaye next I mote paye
An hundred frankes or ellis I am lorne
Yet were me leuyr that I were vn borne
Than me were don sclaunder or vylanye
And yef myn husbonde eke myght aspye
I ner but lost ⁊ therfore I you preie
Lene me this sōmme for ellis mote I deie
Dan Iohn I saye lene me thes hundrid frankes
ꝐPerde I woll not faile you my thankes
If you list to don that I you praie
For a certeyn daye I woll you paie
And to done to you what plesaunce ⁊ seruyse
That you list ⁊ in what wise
And but I do god take on me vengeaunce
As foule as euyr had Genilon of Fraunce
This gentill Monk answerde on this manere
Now truly myn owne lady dere
I haue ꝙquod he on you so gret a routhe
That I you swere ⁊ plight you my trouthe
That whan your husbonde is to Flaundris fare
I woll delyuer you out of this worldis care
I woll bryng you an hundrid frankes
And with that he caught her bi the schankes
And hir enbraced harde ⁊ kiste hir ofte
Goth now your weie ꝙquod sche all stille ⁊ softe
And lete vs dyne as sone as euyr ye may
For be my stomak it is pryme of the day
Goth now ⁊ beth as trewe as I schall be
Or ellis god for bede sir ꝙquod sche
And forth sche goth as ioly as a pye
And bad the Cokes that thei schulde hem hye
So that men myght dyne ⁊ that a non
Vp to hir husbonde is this wif gon
And knocked at his counter boldely
Qe la ꝙquod he . petir it am I
Quod sche . what how long woll ye faste
How long tyme woll ye rekene ⁊ caste
Your sommes ⁊ bokes ⁊ your rekenynges
The deuyll haue parte in all suche thynges
Ye haue y nough parde of goddes honde
Come doun to daye ⁊ lete your bagge stonde
Ne be ye not a schamed that dan Iohn
Schall fastyng be all this daye so long gon
What lete vs here masse ⁊ go dyne
Wife ꝙquod this man litell canst thou deuyne
The corious besynes that we haue
For of vs chapmen so god me saue
And bi that lord that called is seynt yue
Scarsly amonge twenty two of vs schall thryue
Contynuelly lastyng to our age
We maye well make chere ⁊ good visage

With inuysible woundis ay vncurable .
That in his guttes carfe so ⁊ bote .
That his peynes wer importable .
And certeynly the wreche was resonable .
For many mannes guttes dide he peyne .
But fro his purpos cursid ⁊ dampnable .
For all his smerte he nolde hym restreyne .
But badde a non apparaile his oost .
And sodeynly or he was of it ware .
God dauntid all his pride ⁊ all his boost .
For he so sore fell out of his chare .
That hurte his lymes ⁊ his skyn to tare .
So that he ne myght go ne ride .
But in a chaier men a boute hym bare .
All for brosed bothe bakke ⁊ side .
The wreche of god hym smote so cruelly .
That in his body wicked wormys crepte .
And ther with all he stonke so horribly .
That non of alle his meyne that hym kepte .
Whethir that he woke or ellis slepte .
Ne myght not the stynke of hym endure .
In this myschef he weiled ⁊ eke wepte .
And knewe god his lorde to fore eny creature .
TO all his oost ⁊ to hym self also .
Ful fulsome was the stynke of his careyne .
No man myght hym bere to ne fro .
And in his stynke ⁊ in his orrible peyne .
He starf full wrecchidly in a moūnteyne .
Thus hath this robour ⁊ homycide .
That many a man made to wepe ⁊ pleyne
Suche guerdon as bilongeth vn to pride .
THe storie of Alisaundre is so comune .
That euery wight that hath discrecioun .
Hath herd somwhat or all of his fortune .
This wide worlde as in conclusioun .
He wan be strengthe or for his hye renoun .
Thei were glad for pees vn to hym sende .
The pride of man ⁊ beest he leide a doun .
Where so he cam vn to the worldis ende .
COmparison myght neuyr be maked .
Bitwene hym ⁊ another conquerour .
For all this worlde for drede of hym hath quaked .
He was of knyghthode ⁊ of fredom flour .
Fortune hym made the hyer of hir honour .
Saue wyn ⁊ wymen no thyng myght hym aswage .
His hye entente in armes ⁊ labour .
So was he full of louyng corage .
What pite were it to hym thogh I you tolde .
Of Darious ⁊ an hundrid thousande mo .
Of kynges prynces ⁊ Erles bolde .
Whiche he conquerid ⁊ broght hym in to wo .
I saie as ferre as men may ride or go .
The worlde was his what schulde I more deuyse .
For thogh I write ⁊ tolde you euyr mo .
Of his knyghthode it myght not suffise .
TWelue yeer he regned as seith Machabe .
Phillipes sone of Macidoyne was he .
That first was kyng of Grece the contre .
O worthi gentill Alisaundre allas ꝙquod he .
That euyr schulde falle in suche degre .
Enpoisonyd of thi folke thou were .
Thi fortune in to an aas hath turned the .
And yet for the ne wepeþ sche neuyr a teere .
Who schall yeue "teeris" men to compleyne .
The deth of gentilnesse ⁊ of fraūnchise .
That all the worlde welde in his demeyne .
And yet hym thoght it myght not suffise .
So full was his corage of hye emprise .
Alas who schall me helpe to endite .
Fals fortune ⁊ poison to dispise .
The whiche two of all this wo I wite .
By wisdom manhode ⁊ be labour .
Fro humblehede ⁊ fro riall mageste .
Vp roos Iulyus the noble conquerour .
That all the Occident bi londe ⁊ bi see .
Be strengthe of honde or ellis bi trete .
And vn to Rome made hem tributarie .
And sithens of Rome the Emꝑperour was he .
Till that fortune waxe his aduersarie .
O myghti Cesar that in Tessalye .
Ayenst pompeous fadir thyn in lawe .
That of the Orient had all the chyualrie .
As fer as the daie begynneth to dawe .
Thorogh thi knyghthode haste hym take ⁊ slawe .
Saue a fewe folke that with pompeous fledde .
For the whiche thou puttest all the Orient in awe .
Thanke fortune that the so well spedde .
But now a litell while I woll be waile .
This pompeous this noble gouernour .
Of Rome whiche that flewe at this bataile .
I seie oon of his men a fals traitour .
His heed of smote to wynne hym fauour .
Of Iulyus ⁊ to hym the heed broght
Allas pompeous of the Orient conquerour .
That fortune vn to suche a fyne broght .
TO Rome ayen repaireth Iulius .
With his tryumphe laureat full hye .
But on a tyme Brutus Casseus .
That euyr hadde of his estate enuye .
Fulll pryuely had made conspiracye .
A yenst this Iulyus in subtilwise .
And caste the place on whiche he schulde dye .
With Boidkyns as I schall you deuyse .
THis Iulyus to the Capitole wente .
Vp on a daie as he was wonte to goon .
And in the Capitole a non hym hente .
This fals Brutus ⁊ oon of his fals foon .
And stiked hym with boidkyns a noon .
With manye a wounde ⁊ thus thei lete hym lye .
But neuyr gronte he at no strook but oon .
Or ellis at two but if his storie lye .
SO manly was this Iulyus of herte .
And so well louyd estatly honeste .
That though his deedly woūndis so sore smerte .
His mantell ouyr his hipes cast he .
For no man schulde se his pryuete .
And as he laie in diyng on a traunce .
And wiste verreily that deed was he .
Of honeste yet had he remembraunce .
Lucane to this storie I recomende .
And to Sweton ⁊ to valeryus also .
That of this storie writeth worde ⁊ ende .
How that these conquerours two .
Fortune was her frende ⁊ after her fo .
No man truste vp on his fauour long .
But haue hir in a waite euyr mo .
Witnesse of alle these conquerours strong .
THis riche Cresus whilom kyng of Lide .
Of whiche Cresus Seisinus sore hym dradde .
Yet was he caught amongis all this pride .
And to be brente men to the fyre hym ladde .
But suche a rayn downe fro the walken schadde .
That queynt the fire ⁊ made hym to escape .
But to be warr yet no grace he hadde .
Till fortune on the galwis made hym gape .
Whan he escapid was can he not stynte .
For to begynne a newe regne a yen .
He wende well for that fortune hym sente .
Suche happe that he escaped thorogh the rayne .
That of his foos he myght not be slayne .
And suche a sweuene vp on a nyght he mette .
Of whiche he was so proude ⁊ eke fayne .
That he in vengeaunce all his herte sette .
Up on a tree he was as hym thoght .
Ther Iubiter hym wische bothe hals ⁊ side .
And Phebus eke a faire twaile hym broght .
To drie hym with ⁊ therfore waxe his pride .
And to his doughter that stood hym be side .
Whiche that he knewe in hye sentence a bounde .
He bad hir telle what it signefide .
And sche his dreme thus expounde .
The tre ꝙquod sche the galwis is to mene .
And Iubiter be tokeneth snowe ⁊ reyne .
And Phebus with his twaile so clene .
Tho ben the sonne stremys for to seyne .
Thou schalt an hanged be fadir certeyne .
Rayne schall the wasche ⁊ sonne schall the drye .
Thus warned sche hym full plat ⁊ full pleyne .
His doughter that callid was Phanye .
AN hanged was Cresus the proude kyng .
His riall trone myght hym not a vaile .
Tregedys is non other maner thyng .
Ne can in synnyng crye ne be waile .
But that fortune alweie woll assaile .
With vnwar stroke the reynes that ben proude .
For whan men trusteth hir than woll sche faile .
And couyr hir bright face with a cloude ;
Here endith the Monkes tale ; war stroke the reynes that ben proude .

div.l: HO ꝙquod the knyght good sir no more of this
That ye han seide is right ynowȝ y wis
And mochell more for litell heuynesse
Is right y nowȝ to mechill folke as I gesse
I seie for me it is a gret desese
Wher as men han ben in gret welthe ⁊ ese
To heryn of her sodeyn fall allas
And the contrarye is ioye ⁊ gret solas
As when a man hath ben in pore estate
And clymbeth vp ⁊ wexeth fortunate
And ther a bideth in prosꝑperite
Suche thyng is gladsom as thynketh me
And thogh suche thyng were goodly for to telle
Ye ꝙquod our Oost be seynt Poules belle
Ye seie right soth this Monke he clappeth loude
He spak how fortune couerid with a cloude
I not neuyr what ⁊ also of a tregedie
Right now ye herde ⁊ ꝑperde no remedie
It is for to be waile ne compleyne
That that is doon ⁊ also it is a peyne
As ye han seide to here of heuynesse
Sir Monke no more of this so god you blesse
Your tale anoieth all this companye
Suche talkyng is not worth a butterflye
For ther ynne is no disport ne game
Wherfore sir Monke daun Piers be yorur name
I praie you hertly telle vs somwhat ellis
For siker nere clynkyng of your bellis
That on your bridell hangeth on euꝰery side
Be heuyn kyng that for vs alle dide
I schall for this fall downe for slepe
All though the slowe had neuyr be so depe
Then had your tale be tolde in vayne
For certeynly as these clerkis sayne
Wher as a man may haue non audience
Nought helpeth to tellen his sentence
And well I woot the substaunce is in me
If any thyng schall well reportid be
Sir saie sūnwhat of huntyng I you praie
Naie ꝙquod the Monke I haue no luste to plaie
Now lete another telle as I haue tolde
Than spak our Oost with rude speche ⁊ bolde
And seide vn to the Nonnes preest anon
Come nere sir preest come hider sir Ion
Telle vs suche thynges as may our hertis glade
Be mery thogh thou ride vp on a Iade
That theigh thyn hors be foule or lene
If he will serue the recke the noght a bene
Loke that thyn herte be mery euyr mo
Yes Ost ꝙquod he so mote I ride or go
But I be mery y wis I woll be blamed
And right a non he hath his tale tamed
And thus he seide to vs euerichon
This swete preest this good man sir Iohn

div.l: A Pore widowe somdell stope in age
Was whilom dwellyng in a narow cotage
Be sides a groue stondyng / in a dale
This / widowe of whiche I tolde you my tale
Sethyns thilke daie that sche was last / a wif
In pacience ladde a full symple lif
For litell / was hir / catell ⁊ hir / rente
Bi husbondrie of / suche as god hir / sente
Sche fonde hir / self ⁊ eke hir / doughtres two
Thre / large Sowis had sche ⁊ no mo
Thre / kyne ⁊ eke a schepe that / hight / malle
Full sotye was hir / boure ⁊ eke hir / halle
In whiche sche ete mony a sklendre mele
Of poynaūnt sauce hir / nedid neuyr / a dele
No deynte morsell passid hir / throte
Hir / diete was a cordaunt / to hir / cote
Replecion ne made hir / neuyr / sike
A / tempre diete was all hir / phisike
And excercise ⁊ hert / sufficeaunce
The goute lettid hir / no thyng to daunce
Ne perplexite schente not hir / heed
No wyne drank / sche neither / white ne reed
Hir boord was seruyd moost / wtith white ⁊ blacke
Milke ⁊ browne breed in whiche sche fonde no lacke
Seynde bacon ⁊ somtyme an eie or tweie
For sche was as it were a maner / of adeie
A gardyn sche hadde enclosid all / a boute
With stickes ⁊ a drie diche with oute
In whiche sche had a cocke that / hight Chaūnteclere
In all the londe of / crowyng was his / pere
His vois was murier / than the murye Orgon
On masse daies that in the chirche goon
Well sikerer / was the crowyng / in his logge
Then is a clocke or an abbeie orlogge
Bi nature he knewe euꝰery ascencioun
Of / Equynoxiall / of / thilke toun
For when degrees . xv . were descendid
Then knewe he that it myght not be amendid
His combe was redder / than the fyne corall
And bateiled as it were a castell wall /
Like asure were his leggis ⁊ his toon
His bille was blacke ⁊ as the Ieet it / schoon
His nailes whitter / than the lilye flour /
And like burnysched golde was his his / colour /
This gentill cocke had in his gouernaūnce
Seuyn hennys for to doon his plesaūnce
Whiche weryn his sistres ⁊ his ꝑperamours
And wondir / like to hym as of colours
Of whiche the fairest / hewed vndir / throte
Was clepid faire damsell / ꝑpertilote
Curteis sche was discrete ⁊ debonaire
And companable / ⁊ bare hir / self / so faire
Sethyns thilke daie that sche was vij. nyght olde
That truly sche hath the hert / in holde
Of Chaunteclere loken in euꝰery lith
He louyd hir / so that / well was hym ther / with
But suche a ioye as it was to here hem syng
When that the bright / sonne gan to spryng
In swete a corde my leef is fare in londe
For thilke tyme as I haue vndirstonde
Beestis / ⁊ briddis / coude speke ⁊ syng
And so bifell / that in the dawnyng
As Chauntecler / amonges his wifes alle
Sat / on his perche that was in the halle
And next / hym sat / this faire ꝑpertilote
This Chaunteclere gan to grone / in his throte
As a man that / is in his dreme drecchid sore
And when that ꝐPertilote thus herde hym rore
Sche was a gast / ⁊ seide hert / dere
What eileth you to grone in this manere
Ye ben a verry sleper / fy for schame
And he answerde ⁊ seide thus madame
I praie you that ye take it noght / a greef /
Be god me mette that I was in suche myscheef /
Right / now that / yet / myn herte is sore a fright
Now god ꝙquod he my sweuyn rede a right /
And kepe my bodye out / of foule prisoun
Me mette that I romyd vp ⁊ doun
With ynne our / yerde wher / as I sawe a beste
Was like an hoūnde ⁊ wolde haue made a reste
Vp on my body ⁊ wolde haue had me deed
His colour / was betwixe white ⁊ reed
And tipped was his taile ⁊ bothe his eeris
With blacke vn like the remenaūnt / of his heeris
His snowte small / with glowyng yen tweie
Yet of his loke for feer / almoost / I deie
This causid me my gronyng douteles
A weye ꝙquod sche fy on you herteles
Alas ꝙquod sche for bi that god aboue
Now haue ye loste myn herte ⁊ my loue
I can noght / loue a cowarde be my feith
For certis what so anye woman seith
We alle desiren if / it myght / be
To han husbondis hardye wise ⁊ fre
And secre ne no nygarde ne no fooll /
Ne hym that / is a gaste of / euery tooll /
Ne non avaūntour / be that god aboue
How durst / ye sayn so for schame vn to your / loue
That eny thyng / myght / make you a ferde
Haue ye no mannes herte ⁊ han a berde
Alas ⁊ can ye be agaste of / sweuenys
Nothyng god woot / but vanyte / in sweuyn is
Sweuyns engendryn of replecyons /
And ofte of fame ⁊ of complexions
When humours ben to habundaūnt in a wight
Certis this dreem whiche ye haue herde to nyght
Cometh of / the gret / superfluyte
Of / your / reed colere perde
Whiche causeth folk to dreme her / dremys
Of / arewis ⁊ of / fires with reed lemys
Of reed beestis that wolen hem bite
Of contecke ⁊ of / whelpis grete ⁊ lite
Right / as the humour / malencolie
Causeth many a man in sleep for to crie
For fere of Beris ⁊ bolis blake
Or ellis blak / deuyls woll hem take
Of / other / humours couthe I telle also
That werkyn many a man in sleep full wo
But I woll / passe as lightly as I can
Lo Caton whiche that was so wise a man
Seide he not thus yeue / no fors of dremys
Now sir / ꝙquod sche when we fle / fro the bemys
For goddis loue as taketh som laxatif
Vp perill / of my soule ⁊ of my lif
I coūnceile you the beste I woll / not lye
That / bothe of / colere ⁊ malencolye
Ye purge you ⁊ for ye schull / not / tarie
Thogh that / in this toun is non Apoticarie
I schall / my self / to herbis techyn yow
That schall / be your / hele ⁊ your / prow
And in the gardyn two herbis schall I fynde
The whiche haue of her ꝓproprete be kynde
To purgen you bi nethe ⁊ eke a boue
For yetith noght this for goddis owne loue
Ye ben full colrike of / complexion
Wher / the sonne in his ascencion
Ne fynde you replete of / your / humours hote
And if / it do I dar / well leie a grote
That ye schull / haue a feuyr / terciane
Or an Ague that may be your / bane
A daie or two ye schull haue digestyues
Or wormys or ye take your / laxatifes
Of / laureall / Centaure ⁊ of / fumytere
Or ellis of / Ellebore that growith there
Of Catapuce or of / gaites bueries
Of herbe yue growyng in our / yerde / ther / mery is
Pecke hem vp right as thei growe ⁊ ete hem yn
Be mery husbonde for your / fadris kynne
Dredith no dreem I can saie you no more
Madame ꝙquod he gromercy of / your / lore
But natheles as touchyng / daun Catoun
That hath of / wisdom suche gret renoun
Bi god men may in olde bokes rede
Oon of the grettist / auctour / of drede
Of many a man more of / auctorite
Than euyr / Caton was so mote I the
That alle the reuerce seyn of / this sentence
And han well / founden be experience
That dremys ben signyficacions
As well of / ioye as of tribulacions
That folke enduryn in this lif / present
Ther nedith not / to make of / this non argument
The verry preef / schewith it in dede
Oon of / the grettist / auctours þtat men of / rede
¶ Seith thus that / whilom two felawis went /
On pilgrymage in full good entent /
And happid so thei comyn in to a toun
Wher / as / ther / was suche congregacioun
Of / peple ⁊ eke of / streite herbigage
That / thei fonde as moche as a cotage
In whiche thei bothe myght / y logged be
Wherfore thei musten of necessite
As for that nyght / deꝑpertyn of / companye
And eche of hem goth in to his Ostelrye
And took / his loggyng as it wolde falle
That oon of / hem was logged in a stalle
Fer in a yerd with Oxen of the plogh
That other / man was logged well / y nogh
As was his auenture or his fortune
That vs gouerneth all / as in comune
And so bifell / long / er / it / was daie
This man mette in his bedde ther / as he laye
How that his felaw gan on hym calle
And seide alas for in an Oxe stalle
This nyght / schall I be murderid ther / I lie
Now helpe me dere brother / or I die
In all hast / come to me / he seide
This man out / of his sleep for feer / a breide
But when that he was wakenyd out / of / his sleepe
He turneth hym ⁊ toke of / this no kepe
Hym thoght / his dreem was noght but a vanyte
Thus twies in his slepyng dremyd he
And at / the thrid tyme yet / his felawe
Come as he thoght / I am now slawe
Beholde my blodye woūndis depe ⁊ wide
Arise vp erly in the morow tide
And at the westgate of the towne ꝙquod he
A Carte full / of / donge / ther / schalt / thou se
In whiche his bodye is hid full pryuely
Do thilke carte a restyn boldely
Mi golde causid my mordre soth to sayne
And tolde hym euꝰery poynt how he was slayne
With a full / pitous face pale of / hewe
And trust well / his dreem he fonde full / trewe
For on the morne as sone as it was daie
To his felawis yn he toke the waie
And when he come to the Oxe stalle
Aftir / his felawe he bi gan to calle
The Osteler / answerd hym a non
And seide sir / your / felawe is gon
As sone as daie he went / out / of / the toun
This man gan falle in gret / suspecioun
Remembryng on his dremys that he mette
And forth he goth no lenger / wolde he lette
Vn to the westgate of / the toun ⁊ fonde
A dōmgge Carte as he went / to dong the londe
That was araied in the same wise
As ye han herd the deed man deuyse
And with an hardye hert / he gan to crie
Vengeaunce ⁊ Iustice of / this vilanye
Mi felawe murdrid is this same nyght /
And in this Cart / he lieth gapyng vp right
The deed man that murdrid was all newe
O blisfull god that art so iust / ⁊ trewe
Lo how that / thou be wriest / murdre alwaie
Murdre / will out that se we daye be daie
Murdre / is so wlatsome ⁊ so abhomynable
To god that is so iust / ⁊ resonable
That he ne woll / not / suffre it / helid be
Theigh it a bide a yeer / or two or thre
Murdre will / out this is my conclusioun
And right anon mynystris of the toun
Hath hent the Carter / ⁊ sore hym peyned
And eke the Ostler / so fer / engeyned
That thei be knewe her / wickednes a non
And weren hanged bi the necke boon
Here may men se that dremys ben to drede
And certis in the same book / I rede
Right in the next Chapitre I rede of this
I gabbe not / so haue I ioye or blis
¶ Two men that woldyn haue passed the see
For certeyn cause in to a fer / contre
If that the wynde ne had ben contrarie
That made hem in a Cite for to tarie
That stood full / merye vp on an hauen side
But on a daie a yenst the euyn tide
The wynde gan chaūnge ⁊ blowe as hym lest
Iolif / ⁊ glad thei wentyn vn to rest /
And castyn hem full / erly for to saile
But herkyn how oo man fell / in gret ꝑperaile
That oon of / hem in slepyng as he laie
Hym mette a wondir / dreem a yenst the daie
Hym thoght a man stood bi his beddis side
And hym comaūndid that / he schulde a bide
And seide hym thus if / thou to morne wende
Thou schalt / be dreynt / my tale is at an ende
¶ He woke ⁊ tolde his felawe what / he mette
And praied hym his viage for to lette
As for that daie he praied hym to a bide
His felawe that laie be his beddis side
Gan for to laugh ⁊ scornyd hym full / faste
No dreem ꝙquod he may myn hert / a gaste
That I woll / lette for to do my thynges
I sette noght a strawe be dremynges
For sweuenys ben but / vanyteis ⁊ iapes
Men dreme alwaie of Owlis ⁊ of / Apes
And of / many a mase ther / with all /
Men dremyn of thyng that neuyr / was ne schall
But / sithen I se thou wilt / here a bide
And thus for sleuthen wilfully thi tide
God woot / t rewith me ⁊ haue good daie
And thus he toke his leue ⁊ went / his waie
And er / that he had half his cours assailed
But I not / whi ne what myschaūnce it / ailed
But casuelly the schippes botme rent /
And schip ⁊ man vndir / the watir / it went
In sight / of other / schippes hym be side
That / with hym seiled at the same tide
And therfore he seide ꝐPertilote so dere
Bi suche ensample olde / maist / thou lere
That no man schulde be to recheles
Of dremys for I saie the douteles
That mony a dreem full / sore is for to drede
Lo in the lif of seynt / Kenelme I rede
That was Kenulphis sone the noble kyng
Of Mertenrike how Kenelme mette a thyng
A litull / or he was murdrid on a daie
His murdre in his a vision he saie
His Norice hym expowned euꝰery dell /
His sweuyn ⁊ bad hym for to kepe hym well
For treson but he was seuyn yeer / olde
And therfore litell tale hath he tolde
Of any dreem so holly was his his herte
Be god I had leuyr / than my scherte
That / ye had herd his legende as haue I
Dame ꝐPertilote I saie you trewly
Macrobeus that writ / the a vision
In Affrike of / the worthi Ciprion
Affermyth dremys ⁊ seith that ther / ben
Warnyng of / thynges that / men after / seen
And furthermore I praie you loketh well /

(base) And here folweth the prologe of the Manciples tale

div.l: (base) Awake thow Cook quod he god yeue thee sorwe
(base) What eyleth thee to slepe by the morwe
(base) Hastow had fleen al nyght or artow dronke
(base) Or hastow with som quene al nyght yswonke

(base) This Cook that was ful pale and no thyng reed
(base) Seyde to oure hoost so god my soule blesse
(base) As ther is falle on me swich heuynesse
(base) Noot I nat why that me were leuere slepe

(base) Wel quod the Manciple if it may don ese
(base) To thee sir Cook and to no wight displese
(base) Which that here rideth in this compaignye
(base) And that oure hoost wole of his curteisye
(base) I wole as now excuse thee of thy tale
(base) For in good feith thy visage is ful pale
(base) Thyne eyen daswen eek as that me thynketh
(base) And wel I woot thy breth ful soure stynketh

(base) Of me certeyn thow shalt nat ben yglosed
(base) Se how he ganeth lo this dronken wight
(base) As though he wolde swolwe vs anon right
(base) Hoold cloos thy mouth man by thy fader kyn

(base) Thy cursed breeth infecte wol vs alle
(base) Fy stynkynge swyn fy foule mote thee falle

(base) Now swete sire wol ye Iusten atte Fan

(base) I trowe that ye dronken han wyn ape
(base) And that is whan men pleyen with a straw
(base) And with his speche the Cook wax wroth and wraw

(base) For lakke of speche and doun the hors hym caste

(base) This was a fair chyuachee of a Cook
(base) Allas he nadde yholde hym by his ladel

(base) Ther was gret showuyng bothe to and fro

div.l: (base) And fneseth faste and eek he hath the pose

div.l: (base) and beginneth his tale
(base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adoun

(base) Ne koude by an hondred thousand deel
(base) Syngen so wonder myrily and weel
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a wyf
(base) Which that he louede moore than his lyf
(base) And nyght and day dide euere his diligence
(base) Hire for to plese and doon hire reuerence

(base) For hym were looth byiaped for to be

(base) A good wyf that is clene in werk and thoght

(base) And trewely the labour is in vayn
(base) To kepe a shrewe .for it wol nat be

div.l: (base) This holde I for a verray nycetee
(base) To spille labour for to kepe wyues

(base) As to destreyne a thyng which that nature
(base) Hath naturelly set in a creature
(base) Take any bryd and put it in a Cage
(base) And do al thyn entente and thy corage
(base) To fostre it tendrely with mete and drynke
(base) Of alle deyntees that thow kanst bithynke
(base) And kepe it also clenly as thow may

(base) Yet hath this bryd by twenty thousand fold
(base) Leuere in a Forest that is rude and cold
(base) Gon ete wormes and swich wrecchednesse

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth the Persons tale

(base) Iere 6o State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et inuenietis refrigerium animabus vestris et cetera

(base) Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole
perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche
of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
(base) amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise

(base) Stondeth vp on the weyes and seeth and axeth of olde pathes that is to seyn of olde sentences which is the goode
wey
(base) and walketh in that wey and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules et cetera

(base) Manye been the weyes espirituels that leden folk to oure lord Ihesu crist and to the regne
of glorie

(base) of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and
a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey
of Ierusalem celestial

(base) and this wey is clepid Penitence
of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al
his herte

(base) to wite what is penitence and whennes it is
clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions
or werkynges of penitence

(base) and how manye spices ther
ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
whiche thynges destourben penitence

(base) Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of
man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon
any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

(base) And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath
mysdoon

(base) Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray
repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother
peyne for hise giltes

(base) and for he shal be verray penitent
he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and
stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe
and to doon satisfaccioun

(base) and neuere to doon thyng for which
hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle

(base) For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and a gabbere and
no verray repentant that eft soone dooth thyng for which hym
oghte repente

(base) wepynge and nat for to stynte to do synne
may nat auaile

(base) But nathelees men shal hope that at euery
tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh
penitence if he haue grace but certeynly it is greet dowithe

(base) for
as seith Seint Gregorie vnnethe ariseth he out of his synne
that is charged with the charge of yuel vsage

(base) and ther fore
repentant folk that stynte for to synne and forlete synne er that
synne forlete hem holy chirche halt hem siker of hire sauacion

(base) and he that synneth and verraily repenteth hym in his laste
holy chirche yet hopeth his sauacioun by the grete mercy of oure
lord Ihesu crist for his repentance but taak the siker wey

(base) and
Now sith that I haue declared yow what thyng is penitence
Now shul ye vnderstonde that ther been iij accions of penitence
(base) The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

(base) Seint
Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may
nat bigynne the newe clene lyf

(base) for certes if he be baptised with
oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray

(base) Another defaute is this that men doon
deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme

(base) The
thridde defaute is that men fallen in venyal synnes after
hire baptesme fro day to day

(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence
of euery day

(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of
hem is solempne Another is commune and the thridde is priuee

(base) Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as
to be put out of holy chirche in lente for slaughtre of children
and swich manere thyng

(base) Another is whan man hath synned
openly of which synne the fame is openly spoken in the contree
and thanne holy chirche by Iugement destreyneth hym for to
doon open penance

(base) Commune penaunce is that preestes enioynen
men communly in certeyn cas as for to goon parauenture naked in
pilgrymage or barefoot

(base) Pryuee penaunce is thilke that men
doon al day for priuee synnes of whiche we shryue vs pryuely
and receyue pryuee penance

(base) Now shaltow vnderstande
what bihoueth and is necessarie to verray parfit penitence and
this stant on iij thynges

(base) Contricioun of herte Confessioun of
Mouth and Satisfaccioun

(base) for which seith Seint Iohn Grisost
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
omus
Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym
is enioyned with contricioun of herte and shrift of Mowithhe with satisfaccioun and in wirkynge of alle manere humylitee

(base) and this is
fruytful penitence agayn iij thynges in whiche we wrathe oure
lord Ihesu crist
(base) this is to seyn by delit in thynkynge by recchelesnesse in spekynge by wikked synful wirkynge

(base) and agayns
thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree

(base) The roote of this tree is contricioun that hideth hym in the herte of
hym that is verray repentant right as the roote of a tree hideth
hym in the erthe

(base) Of the roote of Contricioun spryngeth a stalke
that bereth branches and leues of confessioun and fruyt of satisfaccioun

(base) for which crist seith in his gospel dooth digne fruyt
of penitence for by this fruyt may men kNowe this tree and
nat by the roote that is hyd in the herte of man ne by the branches ne the leues of Confessioun

(base) And therfore oure Lord Ihesu crist
seith thus by the fruyt of hem shul ye kNowe hem

(base) Of this
roote eek spryngeth a Seed of grace the which Seed is moder
of Sikernesse and this Seed is egre and hoot

(base) the grace of thys
Seed spryngeth of god thurgh remembrance on the day of dome
and on the peynes of helle

(base) Of this matere seith Salomon that
in the drede of god man forleteth his synne

(base) the hete of thys
seed is the loue of god and the desirynge of the Ioye pardurable

(base) this hete draweth the herte of man to god and dooth hym hate
his synne

(base) for soothly ther is no thyng that sauoureth so wel
to a child as the mylk of his norice ne no thyng is to hym
moore abhomynable than thilke mylk whan it is medled with
oother mete

(base) right so the synful man that loueth his synne
hym semeth it is to hym moost swete of any thyng

(base) but fro that
tyme that he loueth sadly oure lord Ihesu crist and desireth the lyf
pardurable ther nys to hym no thyng moore abhomynable

(base) for soothly the lawe of god is the loue of god for which
Dauid the prophete seith I haue loued thy lawe and hated wikkednesse and hate he that loueth god kepeth his lawe and his word

(base) this tree saugh the prophete Daniel in Spirit vp on the auysion of
Nabugodonosor whanne he conseiled hym to do penitence

(base) Penance is the tree of lyf to hem that it receyuen and he that holdeth
hym in verray penitence is blessed after the Sentence of Salomon

(base) In this penitence or Contricioun man shal vnderstonde
iiij thynges that is to seyn what is Contricioun and whiche
ben the causes that moeuen a man to Contricioun and how he
sholde be contrit and what Contricioun auaileth to the soule

(base) thanne
is it thus that Contricioun is the verray sorwe that a man receyueth
in his herte for hise synnes with sad purpos to shryue hym and to
do penance and neuere moore to do synne

(base) and this sorwe shal ben
in this manere as seith Seint Bernard It shal ben heuy and
greuous and ful sharpe and poynaunt in herte

(base) first for man hath
agilt his lord and his Creatour and moore sharp and poynaunt
for he hath agilt his fader celestial

(base) and yet moore sharpe and
poynaunt for he hath wrathed and agilt hym that boughte hym
that with his precious blood hath delyuered vs fro the bondes of synne and fro the creweltee of the deuel and fro the peynes of helle

(base) The causes that oghten moeuen

a man to Contricioun been vj
ffirst a man shal remembren hym of hise synnes

(base) but looke
that thilke remembrance ne be to hym no delit by no wey but gret

werkes worthy of Confessioun

(base) And therfore seith Ezechie I
wol remembre me alle the yeris of my lyf in bitternesse of myn
herte

(base) And god seith in the Apocalipes Remembre yow fro whennes that ye ben falle for biforn that tyme that ye synned ye
were the children of god and lymes of the regne of god

(base) but
for youre synne ye ben woxe thral and foul and membres of
the feend hate of Aungeles Sclaundre of holy chirche and
foode of the false serpent perpetuel matere of the fyr of helle

(base) And yet moore foul and abhomynable for ye trespasen so ofte
tyme as dooth the hound that retorneth to ete his spewyng
